title: Villa Manin
text:
Villa Manin at Passariano is a <a href="Republic%20of%20Venice">Venetian</a> <a href="villa">villa</a> located in Passariano of <a href="Codroipo">Codroipo</a>, <a href="province%20of%20Udine">province of Udine</a>, northern <a href="Italy">Italy</a>.
It was the residence of the last <a href="Doge%20of%20Venice">Doge of Venice</a>, <a href="Ludovico%20Manin">Ludovico Manin</a>. <a href="Napoleon%20Bonaparte">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> and <a href="Josephine%20de%20Beauharnais">Josephine de Beauharnais</a> lived there for about two months in 1797. Here were conducted many interviews for the signing of the treaty between <a href="France">France</a> and <a href="Austria">Austria</a> known as the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Campoformio">Treaty of Campoformio</a> (17 October 1797).
The villa Manin was restored in the 1960s. It hosts a museum and since 2004 to 2008 was a <a href="contemporary%20art">contemporary art</a> center and hosted major international exhibitions.
The building.
It is a monumental architectural complex built in the sixteenth century at the behest of the noble Friulian Antonio Manin who, at the loss of the dominion of the seas, focused on the resources offered by the mainland, setting up a farm and putting a <a href="manor%20house">manor house</a> at his center.
The Manin family, documented in <a href="Florence">Florence</a> since 1000, had arrived in <a href="Friuli">Friuli</a> (<a href="Aquileia">Aquileia</a> and <a href="Cividale">Cividale</a>) as a result of the struggles between the <a href="Guelphs%20and%20Ghibellines">Guelphs and Ghibellines</a> and held that role and the politics in mainland of Venice which will be fully developed in the sixteenth century, a time when Antonio Manin came into possession of the "<a href="gastald">gastald</a>ato" of <a href="Sedegliano">Sedegliano</a> and settled in Passariano.
The first factory of the villa is dated between 1650 and 1660.
In the following years, the grandchildren Ludovico Manin I and Francesco IV took up the project, perhaps aided by the architect Giuseppe Benone. The original appearance of the seventeenth-century villa was radically different from the current one, due to the transformations and enlargements in eighteenth century by Ludovico II and Ludovico III (called Alvise), made first by the Venetian architect <a href="Domenico%20Rossi%20%28architect%29">Domenico Rossi</a> (who in 1707 designed the square plaza and, after 1718, perhaps realizes the current monumental <a href="exedra">exedra</a>), and then by Giovanni Ziborghi, who between 1730 and 1740 did raise the "barchesse" (barn wings). The raising of the noble central core, built with the consulting of <a href="Giorgio%20Massari">Giorgio Massari</a>, was realized after 1745. The large garden (over 17 acres) in the back appears to be due to the will of the "master of the house" Ziborghi.
The nephew, Ludovico Manin, later transformed it into an organic complex that, in addition to agricultural functions, also reflects a desire for social representation.
Substantial interventions of nineteenth century, especially by <a href="Giannantonio%20Selva">Giannantonio Selva</a>, modified the original garden, giving us today a place complicated by the alterations and replacements of the same tree species.
Chapel of Sant'Andrea.
To the villa complex also belongs the chapel of Sant'Andrea (<a href="St.%20Andrew">St. Andrew</a>), built in the early eighteenth century (1708) by <a href="Domenico%20Rossi%20%28architect%29">Domenico Rossi</a> and located outside the square plaza adjoining the "barchessa" and to the east gate. The building is square with rounded corners (almost an <a href="octagon">octagon</a>). The façade, with gable and two pairs of columns at sides is adorned on the edge of the pediment with statues and marble groups by Pietro Baratta. Inside, in the sacristy, there are two marble altars by <a href="Giuseppe%20Bernardi-Torretti">Giuseppe Bernardi-Torretti</a>, and in the hall two other marble altars with <a href="altarpiece">altarpiece</a> worked in relief by the same Torretti.
Decoration.
As well as a fine piece of architecture, the villa is also important for the eighteenth-century artworks. The villa is decorated with frescoes by <a href="Ludovico%20Dorigny">Ludovico Dorigny</a>, <a href="Jacopo%20Amigoni">Jacopo Amigoni</a> and <a href="Pietro%20Oretti">Pietro Oretti</a>, paintings by <a href="Francesco%20Fontebasso">Francesco Fontebasso</a> and sculptures by Torretti.
In a room to the east, in 1708, the Parisian Ludovico Dorigny frescoed on the ceiling, within the central round, the "Triumph of Spring" and the four smaller ovals surrounding the allegories of "Love, Glory, Wealth, <a href="Abundantia">Abundantia</a>". His painting, in cool and dazzling colors preferring elegant figures on a background of clear skies and adopting reckless solutions (<a href="cherubs">cherubs</a> and <a href="nymphs">nymphs</a> on clouds going beyond the frame), is on the whole academic and conventional. On the walls, in <a href="monochrome">monochrome</a> on golden background, are painted some scenes with <a href="Apollo%20%28mythology%29">Apollo</a> and <a href="Mars%20%28mythology%29">Mars</a>, <a href="Venus%20%28mythology%29">Venus</a> and <a href="Bacchus%20%28mythology%29">Bacchus</a>, the <a href="Judgement%20of%20Paris">Judgement of Paris</a>, and <a href="Pan%20%28mythology%29">Pan</a> and <a href="Syrinx">Syrinx</a> between various allegorical figures. The paintings show the "<a href="chiaroscuro">chiaroscuro</a>" of French taste, and inspired the young <a href="Tiepolo">Tiepolo</a>, called to work at the <a href="Archbishopric%20of%20Udine">Archbishopric of Udine</a> in 1726–1730.
Recent history.
In 1962, the villa Manin became property of the "Ente Ville Venete" (now Istituto Regionale Ville Venete - Venetian Villas Regional Institute) by ministerial decree of public interest, which authorized the expropriation at the symbolic price of 140 million <a href="Lira">Lire</a>: a price of bankruptcy liquidation considering the state of abandonment in which stood the residence of the last Doge Ludovico Manin.
The Venetian Villas Authority began the restoration of the villa at a cost of about 200 million Lire. The question was the destination of Villa once restored, with a usable area of 1,800 square meters and a 19-hectare garden. In this climate of uncertainty, the project by Aldo Rizzi (art historian and director of the Civic Museums of Udine) to take the ancient noble residence a prestigious venue for major art exhibitions met the favor of the Municipality of Udine. This idea found the favor of the Autonomous Region of Friuli-Venezia Giulia, which in 1969 bought the villa from the Ente Ville Venete. Rizzi, curator of the villa since 1972 to 1993, organized in 1971 the memorable inaugural exhibition of Tiepolo (325,000 visitors) and created, after the earthquake of 1976, the School of Restoration, which saved many masterpieces of art.
The villa was in 2004 - 2008 a <a href="contemporary%20art">contemporary art</a> center. It hosted major international exhibitions, such as the anthology of <a href="Giuseppe%20Zigaina">Giuseppe Zigaina</a> (until 30 August 2009), the great Impressionist exhibition "From Courbet to Monet. The spread of Realism and Impressionism in Central and Eastern Europe" (26 September 2009 - 7 March 2010), the exhibition "Munch and the spirit of the north. Scandinavia in the late nineteenth century" (September 2010 - March 2011).
Villa Manin was also home to three famous episodes of the international TV show "<a href="Jeux%20Sans%20Fronti%C3%A8res">Jeux Sans Frontières</a>": one in 1972 and two in 1993. It hosted the "<a href="King%20of%20Pain">King of Pain</a>" <a href="Sting%20%28musician%29">Sting</a> tour on 25 July 1993. On 24 July 2008, it hosted the American rock band of <a href="R.E.M.">R.E.M.</a>. On June 28, 2010, <a href="Mot%C3%B6rhead">Motörhead</a> and on 17 August 2010 the British band <a href="Iron%20Maiden">Iron Maiden</a>. On August 13, 2012 it hosted a concert of the <a href="Foo%20Fighters">Foo Fighters</a> and on September 26, 2012 it hosted a concert of <a href="Radiohead">Radiohead</a>. On June 18, 2013 it hosted a concert of the <a href="Kiss%20%28band%29">Kiss</a>, and the July 11, 2013 a concert of <a href="Rammstein">Rammstein</a>.
Collections and exhibitions.
Villa Manin also contains a <a href="museum">museum</a> area of considerable interest for the tourist. The permanent exhibitions are a collection of antique <a href="carriage">carriage</a>s in the stables and an extensive <a href="Armory%20%28military%29">armory</a>, with pieces from the <a href="Casa%20della%20Contadinanza">Casa della Contadinanza</a> of Udine; many of its 350 rooms have been furnished with antique furniture and paintings from the Museum of Udine, including the so-called "Chamber of <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>", where the famous emperor slept, who here signed the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Campoformio">Treaty of Campoformio</a> in 1797.
The villa has hosted important exhibitions of ancient art with prestigious names such as the one cited above of Tiepolo, the <a href="Lombards">Lombards</a>, <a href="Sebastiano%20Ricci">Sebastiano Ricci</a>, and others, to the abstract art of <a href="Wassily%20Kandinsky">Kandinsky</a> in 2003. Exhibitions of <a href="antiques">antiques</a>, concerts and conventions are also noteworthy.
Since 2004 to 2008 Villa Manin Centre for Contemporary Art has been characterized by an annual program that alternated thematic exhibitions with artists from all over the world, collaborations with leading international museums, sculpture projects in the garden, exhibitions dedicated to artists of the local area (Spazio FVG) and various side events. The artistic direction was entrusted to Francesco Bonami. Some exhibitions: "Love Hate From Magritte to Cattelan" (2004), "The Theatre of the Arts - Masterpieces from the collection of the <a href="Ludwig%20Museum">Ludwig Museum</a>", "Luna park fantastic art - Sculpture in the Park" (2005), "Infinite Painting - Contemporary Painting and Global Realism" (2006), "<a href="Hiroshi%20Sugimoto">Hiroshi Sugimoto</a>" (2007), "God & Goods" (2008).
